byline.contributor: Norimitsu Onishi reported from Monrovia, and Sheri Fink from Freetown, Sierra Leone.
byline.original: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and SHERI FINK

abstract: American researchers from National Institutes of Health and their Liberian counterparts are attempting to conduct large study of two vaccines against Ebola but are finding same mix of skepticism, fear and mistrust that helped spread disease in country in first place; vast scale of trial poses its own ethical and practical questions, and complicating matters further is widespread distrust of Liberian government.
lead_paragraph: The same mix of fear and distrust that helped the Ebola epidemic spread is hampering doctors conducting trials on new medicines.

headline.main: Vaccines Face Same Mistrust That Fed Ebola
headline.print_headline: Vaccines Face Same Mistrust That Fed Ebola

snippet: The same mix of fear and distrust that helped the Ebola epidemic spread is hampering doctors conducting trials on new medicines.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
